title: Miguel Almiron will star at Newcastle as soon as he hits first goal, says ex-boss
text:

Miguel Almiron will be a star at St James’ Park as soon as he scores, according to the Atlanta boss who sold him for £21m.

The Paraguay playmaker has yet to find the net in his 18 games since joining Newcastle from the MLS champions in January.

But Atlanta president Darren Eales, a former Tottenham director, revealed Almiron also had a slow start in Georgia.

And the 25-year-old went on to become a huge hit in the States where he won Newcomer of the Year in 2017, the MLS Cup last year – and had the biggest selling shirt in the league ahead of Bastian Schweinsteiger.

“It took Migie a little bit of time to find his feet when he made the move from Paraguay to the Argentinian league and the same with us in our first MLS season,” said Eales at the Leaders in Sport Summit.

“He was unbelievable but he missed a few chances. He went eight games without scoring and had not scored at home and you could feel it getting pent up a little bit.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Then he scored a hat-trick against Houston where everything he hit went in. He got that hat-trick and the floodgates then opened.

“You see his glimpses of his ability. He showed it in the summer with Paraguay at the Copa America

“His pace with the ball is incredible. I always likened it to Gareth Bale from my time at Spurs – he always seems quicker when he has got the ball than without the ball. It is about confidence.

"I just hope he can get that first goal and then they will come in waves.”

Almiron, who was surrounded by Spanish speakers in Atlanta, was bought by Rafa Benitez last season and played with Ayoze Perez and Salomon Rondon.

Now with Steve Bruce he is trying to form new partnerships with new record signing Joelinton and Allan-Saint Maximin.

(Image: Getty Images)

He had only 24 touches in the win over Manchester United and failed to find the target with three shots.

“It is always difficult when you are signed by one manager - a Spanish speaker in particular - and he has now gone,” Eales added.

“But he always works his socks off. He was great going forward for us but he also did the dirty work tackling back.

“He is not primarily a goalscorer but he can score goals, And he is just lightning with the ball in transition. We were just a devastating counter-attacking team when Migie was with us.

"The number of goals where we would just feed him the ball and let him run and he would pass to Jose Martinez to finish the goal.

“If I have got him in my team, I am looking for ways to get him on the break in circumstances where he can use that pace to get beyond the defence.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: The Paraguay striker is yet to hit the back of the net since joining from Atlanta for £21m
